head.title: A Desperate Search for Relief, and for Answers

hedline.hl1: A Desperate Search for Relief, and for Answers

block.p: Re ''Future Face of New Orleans Has an Uncertain Look for Now'' (news article, Sept. 1):
Re ''Future Face of New Orleans Has an Uncertain Look for Now'' (news article, Sept. 1):

My heart goes out to the people suffering from the effects of Hurricane Katrina and their desire to restore their homes and communities. But alternative building plans, like managed retreat from the coastline and stricter building codes, are imperative.
Taxpayers ultimately bear the brunt of rebuilding costs, and they should demand new governmental standards for reclamation of the disaster areas.
Environmental concerns about the Gulf Coast are well documented. The region has a history of major hurricanes and tropical storms, and long-range predictions suggest that this pattern will continue.

Every new hurricane -- when combined with the rising sea level, increased annual precipitation, land subsidence, erosion and loss of coastal salt marshes -- will spell increasing disaster for Gulf Coast residents unless sensible rebuilding occurs.
Does history have to continue to repeat itself, and should taxpayers continue to allow this to happen?
